thread.title: Aust stocks rally 1% at open
thread.title_full: Aust stocks rally 1% at open | Business Spectator

author: Mitchell Neems
title: Aust stocks rally 1% at open
text:
The Australian sharemarket rallied 1 per cent at the open after a rise in commodity prices pushed international bourses higher.
At the 10.15am (AEST) official market open the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index added 52.9 points, or 1.02 per cent, to 5250.8 points, while the broader All Ordinaries rose 51.1 points, or 0.98 per cent, to 5279.5 points.
Rivkin Securities chief executive Scott Schuberg said the mood among Australian investors should remain buoyant today as the rising tide of global equity markets lifts the ASX200 away from vulnerable levels.
"We've been talking a lot about the zones on the ASX200 where we feel 'bullish' or 'bearish' and with yesterday's close of 5198 sitting well above the region that we want to remain above in order to feel positive about this market, investors have reason to feel at ease coming into the end of the week," he said.
Materials led the market higher, adding 2.21 per cent.
BHP Billiton added 3.13 per cent to $25.02, while Rio Tinto gained 3.24 per cent to $53.87.
Energy stocks added 0.86 per cent.
Oil Search added 1.17 per cent to $7.79, while Santos gained 2.56 per cent to $5.20.
Financials gained 0.85 per cent.
Commonwealth Bank rallied 0.89 per cent at $75.67, while ANZ shares added 1.12 per cent to $28.03.
National Australia Bank lifted 0.8 per cent to $31.44 while Westpac gained 0.85 per cent to $30.78.
Consumer staples increased 0.66 per cent.
Wesfarmers shed 0.68 per cent to $40.27, while Woolworths gained 0.8 per cent to $26.46.
Meanwhile, Qantas added 0.27 per cent to $3.73, while Telstra added 0.62 per cent to $5.695.
Locally, in economic news on Thursday, Reserve Bank of Australia head of economic research John Simon is slated to speak at the Paul Woolley Centre for the study of Capital Market Dysfunctionality conference in Sydney. An Australian nickel conference is on in Perth.
In equities news, the Bank of Queensland posted another record full-year result. The news saw BoQ shares rally 5.08 per cent to $12.20.
Meanwhile, at its annual general meeting in Melbourne, Ansell warned its non-US dollar denominated earnings are dragging on the company, as the greenback's strength puts downward pressure on sales revenue. Ansell shares rose 0.59 per cent to $18.64.
In Australia, the market on Wednesday recovered from a midday slump to post a third straight gain, driven by a sustained rally among energy companies.
The benchmark S&P/ASX200 index was up 30.5 points, or 0.59 per cent, at 5197.9 points.
The broader All Ordinaries index was up 29.4 points, or 0.57 per cent, at 5228.4 points
